title: Coalition MP talking points accidentally released
text:
On Treasurer Josh Frydenberg's moves to task the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission with investigating the refusal of the banks to pass on interest rate cuts, the document says "the major banks have decided to put their profits before their customers, and that’s not a good outcome for their customers or the economy".

On Liberal MP Gladys Lui's ties with China, MPs are told "Ms Liu is confident that she is not linked to any organisations that may have inappropriate associations".

On whether the government will heed advice to bring forward infrastructure commitments to spur the economy, it says Mr Morrison has written to the premiers and "Australia does face some capacity constraints in delivering those projects".

In case MPs don't know what the "big stick" energy legislation actually involves, 10 helpful dot points are provided to spell out the bill's potential reach.

These kind of awkward slip ups aren't unheard of.

During this year's federal election campaign, Labor's campaign headquarters sent their talking points out to the travelling press corps on the day of the Liberal launch. It remains unclear if that was an accident.

Labor frontbencher Joel Fitzgibbon went off message in 2013, mocking the Gillard government's attempts at media management and rote reading lines on poor poll results on live TV.

Advertisement

The most revealing sections of Monday's mistake are listed under the heading "If asked".

"If asked: calls for a national drought policy", explain the government's response is strategic.

"If asked about worker exploitation", stress zero tolerance.

"If asked could you live [on] $40 a day," say anything but yes.

If asked about the International Monetary Fund's expectations that Australia will miss its 2030 climate targets, MPs are told to say Australia will meet its commitments without a carbon tax.

The talking points don't say how Australia's rising carbon emissions might complicate matters. More detail is included in the section titled "LABOR'S TAXES".

Facing criticism from the opposition over asylum claims by people arriving in Australia by air rather than boat, Mr Morrison's office blames Labor for the problem and says claims fell by 12 per cent.

Illustrative of much of the rot in modern political communication, the release of the talking points challenge journalists to call out spin in every interview they conduct on Monday.

Attorney-General Christian Porter downplayed the blunder on ABC radio.

"I didn't know that they were [distributed]," he said. These things happen from time to time."
description: Some 18 pages of approved media messages for Liberal and National MPs were sent to the press gallery on Monday morning.
